title: UK halts new weapons exports to Turkey amid military crisis on border with Syria
text:

Britain today bowed to pressure and suspended new arms exports to Turkey after a military crisis escalated on the country's border with Syria.

UK ministers confirmed they will not grant any further export licences for weapons that could be used in military operations in Syria while a review is carried out.

Sources suggested the UK's action was similar taken to that by France and Germany.

But existing export licences - which generally last two to five years - have not been cancelled, which means weapons worth millions can continue to be sold to the country.

The UK granted export licences to Turkey worth £842m in the last three years.

Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab confirmed the move in a statement to the House of Commons.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

He told MPs: "No further export licences to Turkey for items which might be used in military operations in Syria will be granted while we conduct that review."

Andrew Smith of Campaign Against Arms Trade said: "This change cannot only be limited to future arms sales.

"It must also affect the hundreds of millions of pounds worth of arms that have been licensed over recent years.

"As long as those licences are still valid then those arms can be used."

He added: "The UK Government has clearly been shamed into this, but the truth is that it should never have been arming and supporting President Erdogan and his authoritarian regime in the first place."

Donald Trump imposed sanctions on Turkey last night and demanded a ceasefire as a military crisis in the region escalates.

The US President asked Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan to stop a military incursion in northern Syria that is reshaping the battlefield of the world's deadliest ongoing war.

Trump was blamed for sparking the action by pulling US forces out of the conflict zone - home to the Kurdish YPG militia and so-called Islamic State militants.

Now the US President has announced plans to reimpose 50% steel tariffs on Turkey six months after they were cut.

He also signed an executive order authorising sanctions against current and former officials of the Turkish government; halted negotiations on a $100bn trade deal, and requested a ceasefire in a phone call.

Turkey wants to hit the Kurdish YPG militia, the main element of Washington's Kurdish-led ally, the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF).

The group has been a key US ally in dismantling the jihadist "caliphate" set up by Islamic State militants in Syria.

But Turkey regards the YPG as a terrorist group aligned with Kurdish insurgents.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

The Turkish Defence Ministry said 560 militants had been "neutralised" since the operation began. Earlier, Erdogan said 500 militants had been killed, 26 surrendered and 24 were wounded so far.

Mr Raab called on Turkey to "exercise maximum restraint and to bring an end to this unilateral military action".

He added: "This is not the action we expected from an ally. It is reckless, it is counter-productive and it plays straight into the hands of Russia and indeed the Assad regime."

The Syrian army deployment is a victory for President Bashar al-Assad and his most powerful ally, Russia.

It gives the Syrian-Russian alliance a foothold in the biggest remaining swath of the country that had been beyond their grasp.

Shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry said: "The situation in northern Syria has gone from bad to worse, to utterly catastrophic and horrifying since the Trump administration withdrew its troops and gave a green light to Turkey to invade."

Ms Thornberry told the Commons Turkish airstrikes and artillery barrages, as well as "barbaric jihadi death squads", have led to the deaths of dozens of civilians.

Tory MP and former defence minister Tobias Ellwood warned: "Direct conflict between Syria and Turkey is now just another notch closer."

He said: "In just a week we've seen the map of north-east Syria redrawn following the ill thought through foreign policy change by President Trump which has triggered a tragic series of events now undermining international efforts to contain Daesh.

"What discussions has he (Mr Raab) had with his US counterparts to invite them to re-engage with the international community on the future of Syria? They cannot back out of their international responsibilities.

"We speak of the erosion of the rules-based order. Does this not send a worrying message to Russia, given its resurgent activities in eastern Europe, and China with its claim over much of the South China Sea, if the West does not have the resolve to defend international standards when they are breached by a Nato ally."

International Trade Secretary Liz Truss said: “We continue to monitor the situation in Syria very closely and are considering the licensing position in the light of recent developments.

“No further export licences to Turkey for items which might be used in military operations in Syria will be granted while we do so.

“My Department will take into account any developments in the operations in Syria as part of our rigorous licensing process.”

She added: "The UK has, for some time, been carefully considering export licence applications for Turkey in light of Turkish activities in Syria.”
description: No new arms export licences will be granted amid a review of violence on the border with Syria - yet millions of pounds worth of existing licences are still in force
